comment.author: 52585175@N07
comment._content: I don't know- but I want one to dig my allotment with!!?

comment.author: 41996436@N08
comment._content:
The infernal machine is a steam excavator, a 'crane navvy' built by John H. Wilson of Liverpool. The 'roof' looks like a contractors' improvisation, not supplied by the manufacturer.
[The Liecestershire Record Office have a photo c.1903 of a similar machine, sans roof, in use in the construction of the railway from Wootton Underwood to Haddenham, Buckinghamshire.]

comment.author: 26033330@N00
comment._content: An amazing image. Everything changes, everything remains the same.

comment.author: 36034969@N08
comment._content: Interesting shot of Irish Navvies on home soil. They are so often associated with everybody elses railway projects at that time in history. An unusual crude set of points in the foreground too I guess the length of rail behind the shovel could be placed to allow the muck wagon to be swapped to the other track by horse power without the need for a conventional set of points.

comment.author: 33847785@N00
comment._content: The steam shovel will also have been known as a Navvy. I well remember my Pa talking about them in the 1940s.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33847785@N00] Had already tagged with crane navvy via Jack Falstaff, but have now added navvy too, thanks.

comment.author: 63844591@N04
comment._content: The Terminus of the Waterford Cork railway line was in Waterford South Station in Bilberry until a new railway bridge was built across the Suir c1905 which meant the terminus could be transferred to the Waterford North Station (the present Waterford Railway Station). The cutting at Gracedieu was necessary to redirect the line across the new bridge although the old line into Bilberry was in existence until 1970 and is now part of the Waterford/ Kilmeaden tourist railway.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
